questions.question:
Type 2 inflammation encompasses eosinophilic and 
 allergic asthma phenotypes through the action of 
 key cytokines IL-4, IL-13, IL-5, and the antibody IgE.

Th2 are the only cells responsible for the expression 
 of the type 2 cytokines IL-4, IL-13, and IL-5.
questions.explanation:
ILC2 and Tfh cells also contribute 
 to the type 2 inflammatory profile.

questions.question:
IL-4 has a crucial upstream role in type 2 
 inflammation by driving the differentiation of 
 Th2 cells which contribute to the production 
 of type 2 cytokines.

One overlapping role of IL-4 and IL-13 in the 
 process of type 2 inflammation is their implication 
 in the class switching process of B cells 
 to initiate IgE secretion.

IL-5 and IL-4 both contribute to the accumulation 
 of eosinophils during type 2 inflammation.

In the lungs, the roles of IL-4, IL-13, and IL-5 
 cytokines during type 2 inflammation are solely 
 focused on immune cells.
questions.explanation:
All three cytokines contribute to the structural 
 changes in the airway epithelium and submucosa.
